course_title: Special Topics in Philosophy: Philosophy in a Time of Plague
class_notes:
TOPIC: Philosophy in a Time of Plague
Plagues have been around for millennia and this course provides an overview of theoretical and literary responses to them in the western world. Materials range from Ancient Athens and Rome (Thucydides, Lucretius) to Renaissance Italy (Boccaccio), modern 17th century London (De Foe), 20th century Algiers (Camus), and into the 21st century United States. Theoretical considerations will include Nietzsche's aesthetic opposition between Apollo and Dionysus, Susan Sontag's notion of illness as metaphor, Foucault's conception of plague as provoking a new stage in the history of state power and surveillance, Zizek's connection of the pandemic with communism, and contemporary discussions of racial disparities in COVID-19 treatment access and patient outcomes in the U.S.. We will see that while much has changed over the centuries, much has also eerily stayed the same. A final project will invite students to use course authors and ideas to address the current COVID-19 pandemic as well.
